Did you know that that slimy membrane on fish is a protective shield against pathogens? It remains on them when they are wet, however,  if you touch a fish with dry hands,  the slimy mucus sticks to your skin,, removing it from the fish,  leaving them    vulnerable and susceptible to pathogens if you're intending to release the fish back into the water. People that practice catch and release should wet their hands before touching the fish.  People that practice hook em and cook em don't need to be concerned about that with legal fish

"Many people were confused about why my children say “Yes Sir” and “No Sir”.  Many people have dismissed it as
“just a Southern thing”, or a strange form of authoritarian
brainwashing.  People who feel the need to lump my family in with their
preconceived notions or stereotypes is to be expected.  No, it’s not
just something we do.  No, it’s not me demanding respect from my
children because I’m an egomaniac.  (On second thought, my wife might
have a good counter argument about my selfishness as a human).  I hope
you don’t throw us into one of your categories of “types of people”.
 Consider that we, like many other families, might take the job of
raising awesome people (parenting) so seriously that the results look
strange to normal people.
I did not demand that they say “sir” when I filmed this video, I
simply asked them questions.  They say “sir” when they know I’m trying
to clearly communicate something and they’re letting me know in a very
clear way that they understand.  We take parenting much more serious
than most people you’ve come in contact with.  We don’t try to modify
their behavior, we try to shepherd their hearts.  Brainwashing a child
is selfish, dumb, and destructive.  I understand that most people have
not witnessed a style of parenting  that results in mutual respect
without threats or fear…, so this is understandably confusing to the
masses.  Some think it’s over the top for a child to show respect to their Father.  Then again, some also think it’s over the top to teach a 5 year old Fluid Mechanics.  My wife and I disagree
with both of these groups of people.  We’re not trying to create Angels
or Academics.  We’re simply loving our kids by exploring the world with
them and shepherding their hearts."
-Destin

Hi Destin, the expansion of the buccal cavity and opening of the operculum is also how fish breathe when they are motionless. This technique causes a movement of water over the gills which maintains the diffusion gradient of oxygen:)
Sharks do not use this technique which is why they are always moving, need to keep water flowing over the gills.

Growing up in an Asian-american culture, I have a habit of calling ppl significantly older than me sir or ma'am in Chinese. Eventually I started doing it naturally in English too. Considering how my Asian American community was extremely tight-knit and my parents generation were very familiar and loving to my friends and I, I find it laughable when people comment about their assumptions that his kids must be highly repressed/unloved. Watch a couple more of his videos and you'll start to realize that most kids in America and in the world would be lucky to have a father as loving and caring as Destin.

For those who are wondering why they say "sir" to their dad is simply having manners.

In many countries, they say "sir"to ANYONE who are older than them, especially their relatives/parents etc. In Spanish u say to your elder, " seniorita/senior" in Japanese they say "kun/Chan/senpai/sensei" in tagalog they say "po" after each sentence to show respect to their elder. Its sad that people think this is weird. When in actuality every country have been doing this in forever and its just normal.

2:46 A fine example of how AC power doesn't alternate fast enough to not get caught on high speed footage. If your shooting at high speed stick with a DC or natural light source to avoid a flicker in your video.

@SmarterEveryDay 
On the subject of his son saying "yes sir" and "no sir". I feel that this style of parenting depends on the kid =^_^=
After all, Kids are people too, with thoughts and feelings, they are individuals. Obviously this style of parenting is working for them because they are Great Kids!.

Personally, I didn't respond well to specific styles of Adult Supervision; I was always an independent rebel. I didn't see Adults as being any better than I was, and in many cases I was right. Just because an Adult has more years of life does not mean they are worthy of trust, or respect. Respect must be earned and Demonstrated, and if little BlackPicketSign said "Yes Sir " or "Yes Ma'am" to you, you KNEW that you had earned my respect... otherwise I would never give such titles to people who didn't earn it.

I'm english and I live in the Uk and even I know that using yes sir is a common term for general politeness in parts of America, my godmother for instance sometimes says it to me and she has got a good 20 years on myself, nothing strange about it just different linguistics and cultures. I can see how people who learn English from Europe find this weird as it has an entirely different meaning.

On the third phantom clip of the fish eating, you can see the lights flashing. Don't know if that was an intentional addition or accidental but an excellent visual of phantom time. Since the lights are on what I am assuming is 60Hz AC power, those light are flashing at 120 times per second. The strike takes all of about five flashes. Pretty quick.

It may interest you to know that Barramundi are also known as "Asian Sea Bass" outside of Australia, with 'Barramundi" being settled on as a marketing term to sell domestic product. Destin, this was awesome footage to see! I fish often and love it when a big bass is in clear enough water that I can see it suck in my bait. One note I had: I don't believe that expelling the water out the gills has as much to do with dissipating momentum as it does simply with expelling water in such a way as to not release food the same way it came in. On the inside of a fishes gills there are stiff ribs that act as a cage preventing anything but liquid from passing, so the fish can suck in prey with a large volume of water, then expel the excess through a passage that is impossible for the catch to escape through. If the fish just closed it's mouth without releasing the excess water out another passage, whatever it had just caught would be forcibly spit out.

It's crazy, seeing everyone's perception of the word "sir", as a person that was at least raised in the south, I had no idea it was anything other than simple deference. I said yes sir to my dad plenty, but I wasn't beaten if I didn't or anything. The way I look at it, sir isn't treated nearly as seriously in the south. It's just about knowing at a young age how to get along with each other. I get that kids need fun for their unbridled energy, but having a specific phrase to latch onto as an idea for respect can be a huge help for understanding that emotion in the first place.

As someone originally from the northeast who moved down to Florida for college, I picked up on the habit of saying "sir" and "ma'am". It felt funny and almost too formal/militaristic at first, but many here say it casually as a sign of respect for everyone. That's not to say that a regular "yes" or "no" isn't polite, but it's definitely a regional culture thing, and I've grown to like it.
